prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Olive Green
Description: An art-school student whose ambition is to become an artist. She's just regained consciousness, having been comatose for days after suffering a stab to from the back.
Character 4
Name: Soseki Natsume
Description: A Japanese scholar sent to London to further his research into the English language. He's just been acquitted of a very serious crime.↳A Japanese scholar sent to London to further his research into the English language. He's just been acquitted of a very serious crime, but now finds himself accused of another.
Character 5
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 6
Name: William Shamspeare
Description: The victim of the current case - a failed actor renting a room in the same building as Mr Natsume's lodgings.
Character 7
Name: John Garrideb
Description: A retired army man who's the landlord of the lodgings rented by the defendant, Mr Natsume. An old knee injury means he's confined to a chair most of the time.
Character 8
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 9
Name: Adron B. Metermann
Description: A young man who works for Altamont Gas. He's a witness to the incident.
Character 10
Name: Quinby Altamont
Description: The wife of the owner of the Altamont Gas Company. She's a staunch believer in the superiority of the fuel and utterly unforgiving of gas theft.
Character 11
Name: Duncan Ross
Description: The love of Miss Green's life, who sadly passed away a month ago as a result of gas poisoning.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Secondhand Book Receipt
Description: A receipt for some books that Mr Natsume purchased at a secondhand bookshop. It was submitted as evidence in the trial the other day.
Evidence 2
Name: Nearby Street Map
Description: A street map of the neighbourhood where Mr Natsume has his lodgings. It was submitted as evidence in the trial the other day.
Evidence 3
Name: Pair of Teacups
Description: The teacups used by Mr Shamspeare and Mr Natsume. The one with the green line around the rim was Mr Natsume's. The teacups used by Mr Shamspeare and Mr Natsume. There is no tea ring on the inside of Mr Natsume's cup.
Evidence 4
Name: Torn-Off End of Envelope
Description: A ripped piece of an envelope that was found in Mr Shamspeare's room. The rest of the envelope could not be located. A ripped piece of an envelope that was found in Mr Shamspeare's room. It fits perfectly with an envelope in Miss Green's possession.
Evidence 5
Name: Bar of Soap
Description: A cheap bar of soap that was discovered just outside Mr Shamspeare's window. It's one of two that were found there. A cheap bar of soap that was discovered just outside Mr Shamspeare's window. There is a two centimetre diameter circular depression in the middle of one surface.
Evidence 6
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the scene taken by police upon their arrival. The victim can be seen unconscious at the table, having been poisoned.
Evidence 7
Name: Victim's Medical Report
Description: A report issued by Scotland Yard's medical officer. It obviously mentions the poison as well as other details gleaned during the police investigation.
Evidence 8
Name: Gas Meter
Description: A meter that dispenses gas for a set time after a coin is inserted. It sports a very strong lock, especially with Mr Shamspeare in mind. A meter that dispenses gas for a set time after a coin is inserted. The attached coin box sports a very strong lock, and there is a tiny hole in its base.
Evidence 9
Name: Handprints on the Wall
Description: Traces of handprints on the wall, discovered using the Skin Print Seeker gun. There are multiple prints on either side of a hanging picture.
Evidence 10
Name: Capital Offender Article
Description: A newspaper article about Selden, a criminal sentenced to receive the death penalty. However, he died of illness in prison whilst his loot remained undiscovered.
Evidence 11
Name: Hidden Photograph
Description: A photographic print found in Mr Shamspeare's room. It shows the landlord, Mr Garrideb, together with a young man.
Evidence 12
Name: Bottle of Poison
Description: A bottle found in the possession of Miss Green with traces of the slow-acting poison strychnine inside.
Evidence 13
Name: Capital Offender's File
Description: Scotland Yard's file about the convicted criminal Selden that includes the newspaper article about him dying of illness in prison.
Evidence 14
Name: Miss Green's Card
Description: A note in an envelope that seems to have been ripped open rather roughly. It contains instructions to meet with someone who claims to have information about Duncan Ross. A note in an envelope that seems to have been ripped open rather roughly. The envelope fits perfectly with a torn-off piece found at the scene of the crime.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The Japanese man did come to my chamber with tea brew'd in a pot.
Person: Shamspeare
Testimony 1
Testimony: 'Twas in my cup alone that the wicked miscreant secretly pour'd his wicked poison.
Person: Shamspeare
Testimony 2
Testimony: Whilst feigning distraction in our debate, ne'er did a drop of his own drink pass his lips.
Person: Shamspeare
Testimony 3
Testimony: When he departed by and by, I did use the tea that remain'd in his cup to make my coins of ice.
Person: Shamspeare
Testimony 4
Testimony: Thus 'tis no surprise that poison be not found in the tea I did pour into the moulds of soap.
Person: Shamspeare

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot: Evidence 3 (Pair of Teacups) states that there is no tea ring on the inside of Mr Natsume's cup, implying that Mr Natsume did not drink from his cup. However, Testimony 1 by Shamspeare suggests that the Japanese man did not drink from his cup, and that he poured the poison into Shamspeare's cup. This contradicts the evidence, as the evidence suggests that Mr Natsume's cup was not used, while the testimony suggests that Mr Natsume did not drink from his cup.

Testimony 0
Testimony: It was six days ago, at about 5 p.m. I was walking along in the snow when I was suddenly stabbed in the back.
Person: Green

Testimony 2

Testimony 3
Testimony: It was the first time I'd been in the area. I had a little matter to attend to, that's all.
Person: Green
Testimony 4
Testimony: Anyway, I was admitted straight to hospital, so I knew nothing about all of this business.

cot: Evidence 5 (Bar of Soap) states that a cheap bar of soap was discovered just outside Mr Shamspeare's window, with a two centimeter diameter circular depression in the middle of one surface. However, Testimony 0 by Green suggests that she was stabbed in the back six days ago, at about 5 p.m., and was walking along in the snow when she was stabbed. This contradicts the evidence, as the evidence suggests that the bar of soap was found outside Mr Shamspeare's window, while the testimony suggests that Green was stabbed in the back, not poisoned, and does not mention the soap.

Testimony: I do remember now. 'Twas a week ago, peradventure, that note was deliver'd unto me.
Person: Shamspeare

Person: Shamspeare

Testimony: Thereafter, on the evening I shared the company of the Japanese fellow, I did see the note had vanish'd.
Person: Shamspeare
Testimony 3
Testimony: I don't know what you mean. You think I snuck into this man's room, do you? Why would I?
